• Please share an example of how you use it in your practice (if you do) OR an example of how you could imagine using it in your practice (if you do not)? 
    • If both apply to you, please feel free to share a response to both questions. 

So I sometimes will use this routine when asking students to do some initial sensemaking about something, and find it to be a productive initial scaffold that gets kids looking for patterns/structure/salient features and asking mathematical questions and/or making conjectures. For example, in a course that I've taught that focuses on the mathematics of perfect shuffles, the students are asked to build a table (n, o(n)) that tracks the number of out-shuffles, o(n), as a function of the deck size, n. The first few values of o(n) (for n even) are 1, 2, 4, 3, 6, 10, 12, 4, 8, 18, 6, 11, ... Asking students to notice and wonder creates really productive discussion - students have all sorts of conjectures about how to predict additional entries in the table, almost always expressed in terms of the elementary functions they are familiar with (polynomials, exponentials, etc).


All that having been said, I tend to think of N&W as just one tool in the toolkit for orienting kids towards mathematical structure, and I tend to use it less as we get deeper into a problem.

Subject: RE: Notice and Wonder
Msg Text:
David,


I love the curiosity!  Thanks for asking about this.


Desmos is really fantastic about making their tool accessible to students with visual impairments.  Students can use a screen reader (JAWS or NVDA) to hear what is on the computer screen.  The graph is 'read' to them with sonification.  To use the braille option a student would attach a refreshable braille display to the computer and the text would be represented on the student's device in braille.  A student could also use their regular computer keyboard to enter the braille (this is called 6 key entry), and then use the screen reader to hear it back.  


Each braille character is made up of a combination of 6 cells.  If you google refreshable braille display you will see that there is a series of these 6 dot cells that keep being refreshed as a person reads. 


Finally, there is Nemeth and UEB braille which are two different math languages.  Nemeth has been around for a very long time and in the past few years, UEB has been adopted to standardize how braille is written in English speaking countries.  Students in the US use both codes, depending on the state they live in.


That's a lot of information and I hope I explained it well.  Here is a link if you want to see some videos and get a more professional explanation.  I am always happy to explain how my students do math so feel free to ask any questions! 


https://www.desmos.com/accessibility

Subject: Unpacking Mathematical Thinking - Eating Contest Scenario
Msg Text:
The first thing I did was panic - thinking I really didn't know how to solve this problem. Once I read through the scenario a few times I was able to create formals or mathematical relationships based on Caleb for the other 3 people in the scenario. I tried several times to "solve" this particular math problem, but came up with questions about how you determine exactly what the word "impressive" means - and how to atttibute a number to that descriptive word. 


I tried some different values for Caleb - and then started to think about different age groups - would it be better to be talking about eating an impressive amount of skittles or something more related to students (depending on age). I wanted to see if I saw any patterns in the numbers - maybe graphing them to see if a visual pattern emerges that could give a more blanket statement about what happens when Caleb eats different impressive amounts of green beans. Who defines impressive? There is a part of math that requires justification - why is your thought that 100 beans is impressive more valuable than anothers' thought that 5 beans is impressive (if you hate green beans - that is impressive). 


Sense-making to me has traditionally meant an ability to solve a problem, but as I focus less on procedural mathematics and more on deepening understanding, the sense-making becomes an important piece. This could be a fun activity for students - although, if they are like me, they will be annoyed because there isn't a "solution"

Subject: Eating Contest Problem
Msg Text:
When solving the Eating Contest problem, I first thought about translating the words into algebraic expressions.  I felt comfortable doing this, especially because this is at the heart of seventh grade math, and we just finished our expressions and equations unit, but I was also thinking about how students who were less comfortable with translating words to algebraic expressions (or just mathematical sentences in general) might feel.


I then used the expressions to test some "benchmark" numbers.  I was thinking about the discussion via Zoom and in breakout rooms, and realized how helpful discussing the problem was in thinking about solving the question my group came up with.  For example, I thought a lot about what "impressive" meant as another person had raised the significance of this term in relation to the contest.  I was also thinking about fairness of the contest itself - there was a lot of information we didn't know about the contestants, so maybe "ranking" them wasn't really the point.  Finally, though I used substition to solve the problem, I realized that making a table or a graph would have been great scaffolds and visuals for students, especially when thinking about "tipping points" (the moments when one participant overtook another in the contest).


One "hidden" decision I made when solving the questions of who ate the most and who ate the least was to not deal with fractional green beans.  This could be an interesting discussion for students.  Is a green bean counted as "1" even though it might be larger or smaller than another green bean.  What if they are "broken"?  I dealt mostly with even numbers so that 1/2's would always be "whole" numbers.


Lastly, I would love to think with students about the "merits" and "themes" of this story.  What does it mean for Caleb if the more green beans he eats (based on the scenario) the more likely he is to end up in "last" place?

Subject: Eating contest solution
Msg Text:
Wonder: What is the minimum number of beans to be considered impressive?  Did all kids eat an impressive amount


First I created equations for each kid and then graphed them.  (See attachement)

  

Thinking process:

1.Second I defined impressive based on my opinion of eating beans. Contest was 5 min.  Green beans are terrible so I believe it's impressive if they actually ate 4 per min or 20 beans.

Based on the graph the minimum possible beans eaten was 7.5 because if Caleb ate less then 7.5 the Elsie would have a negative number of beans eaten. I guess she could have thrown up beans from earlier, but let's assume that's not the case. Regardless of how many Caleb ate, Sol at over 20 so he is impressive. For the others we need to solve the following equations: 

Josh, 20 = C + 8 , c=12, so Caleb has to eat 12 or more for Josh to be impressive 

Elsie, 20 = 2C -15 , c=17.5, so Caleb has to eat 17.5 for Elsie to be impressive

Caleb needs to eat 20 for all of them to be impressive Caleb needs to eat 20 since that's where every line is above y = 20 

2. After seeing the graph other questions came up like what are the significant number of beans eatten that change the winner.

Msg Text:
• What did you do first when exploring the Eating Contest wondering(s) your group chose?
  • Reflect on your process of thinking through the Eating Contest wondering, include:
      1. An explanation of the first moves you made when making sense of the eating contest wondering
      2. Share any other thoughts/questions/comments related to any other hidden decisions that came up when you were exploring your wondering(s).

The first thing I did was to write the relationship between the number of beans Caleb ate and each of his friends as an equation. Their totals were all dependent on how many Caleb ate. I started to look for patterns by creating a table and then graphed them on Desmos.


I was expecting to have a single point of intersection, but after working on the problem I realized that wouldn't be possible since no one would eat the same amount as Caleb. I did wonder if more than two people could have the same amount, but the graph provides a great visual answer.


At some point there needed to be a maximum number of beans one could possibly eat in five minutes. My first entry in the table was 10 beans for Caleb. In retrospect this was a low first guess unless he was eating some sort of giant green beans. Ha!

Subject: Unpacking the eating contest problem
Msg Text:
When I initially read the story, I immediately thought of linear programming to see the relationships between the students.  Based on what I teach, it was immediately obvious that this was an inequality problem.  At least, that's how I'd use it in class.  So I wrote out the mathematical relationships given to us in the story and plugged them into Desmos so I could see the math.  With so many, I thought that would be the most efficient way to explore the relationships of the students regarding how many green beans each one ate if Caleb ate X.


I was really intrigued when I discovered that the actual ranking of the students changed depending on Caleb's impressive X not just once or twice, but five times!


I know there was no actual question posed, but after reading the story, I wanted to know how the eaters compared to each other, and most students would also go down this line of thought.  Other questions that came up though included why green beans?  You just watched a hot dog eating contest and green beans is what you went with?  Was it all on a dare then and none of them liked green beans at all?  Did one of them secretly like green beans and dared the others knowing they didn't?  I could see all kinds of conversations being had like this, the social emotional component of the problem, and getting students engaged with it.  Thus, the other "hidden" component of the problem is the definition of the word "impressive."  Well, I googled how many green beans is in a serving, and it's only 20.  Given that the ranking doesn't change after 60 green beans anymore, I am calling "impressive" anything > 60.  I'd probably be inclined to say 100 is impressive, but they did only have 5 minutes to eat, so > 60 is probably enough to qualify.

So I identified my unkown variable x as the number of gb Caleb ate

 x = # gb Caleb ate

x +8 = # green beans Josh ate

Subject: Eating Contest Problem
Msg Text:
After reading the scenario to get a general sense of it, I read it again with more attention to detail. I noticed that the other participants' consumption was expressed in terms of Caleb. I also wondered if partially eaten beans were counted. After that, I started thinking about what questions I could pursue or answer given this information.


Next, I expressed the quanties eaten as algebraic expressions and thought about the ramifications if Caleb ate 0 to 7 beans, as well as if he consumed an odd number of beans. I substituted 8, 10, 12 for Caleb's consumption, calculating other participants' consumption and total beans eaten in a table, noting how others' consumption and total consumption increased (by 2, by 4, by 1, by 9) as Caleb's consumption increased by 2. I


went off on an even/odd number tangent just for fun, noting that some participants' number of beans eaten was always even, others' always odd, and some alternating.


I also extended my exploration past Caleb eating 12 beans, noticing that different people are in the lead in the contest as Caleb's consumption increases, and that sometimes people are tied.


Next, I imagined what a reasonable maximum number of beans eaten in five minutes would be, wanting to establish some kind of upper limit, having already establish some possible lower limits, depending on whether partial beans were counted.

Msg Text:
Hi Rebekah,


I love the norm of starting with "doing something."  Personally, my go to is always taking brief notes on the problem - writing down key details.  It helps me feel like things are in motion.


I also like the idea of starting with numbers like 10 and noticing and wondering from there.  It reminds me of the strategy of then thinking about "too big" and "too small" of a number as a way to work towards the solution.


Finally, I think it is really important to try to take the perspective of our students ("thinking like a 6th grader"). I find it helps me be more aware of where they might go with a given problem, rather than my over-reliance on strategies they haven't been taught yet.  Sometimes I wonder if the "easier" way of doing things algebraically is actually a dis-service to students in the sense that for some, who become quickly frustrated by algebraic expressions, they may also lose the innate ability and wonder/way to approach the problem they may have had when younger.  I'm often impressed when I work with 4th or 5th  graders who seem much more willing to "jump" into problems than some of the 7th graders who I teach.  Some of the 7th graders are so worried about being wrong that it seems to paralyze them. . .which brings us back to your intial point of just doing something. :)

Subject: Eaing contest  - unpacking
Msg Text:
I was trying to answer the question of who at an "impressive" amount, so I wondered if there was a way to compare c, j, e, and s without actually knowing how much each one ate. I generated a set of equations -- all in terms of c -- and tried to develop a set of inequalities that would answer my question. However, I realized that determining who at an impressive amount depended on how much c ate, and that the others had different rates of eating (1, 2, and 1/2, respectively. The importance of the slopes became apparent when I graphed each person's bean-eating function.

One assumption I made was that all bean totals were positive integers.

Another assumption I made was that I allowed for "impressiveness" to vary directly with Caleb's total -- in this case, j is always impressive, e is impressive iff c >= 16, and s is impressive iff n c < 60. However, it's possible impressiveness is fixed at Caleb's minimum (8 beans), in which case c,j, and s are always impressive, and e is impressive iff c >= 12.

Subject: Some Reactions to Y'all's Discussions
Msg Text:
I'm a bit late to the party, but enjoyed reading everyone's thoughts and had a few of my own to add.  I do LOVE how many of you didn't even initially notice that there wasn't a question!


Justin commented that jumping to solution strategies that seem natural to us often doesn't help us support a wider range of student thinking.  When we were writing the Problems of the Week at the Math Forum, we got together weekly for Math Monday (usually on Monday, but not always) and solved potential problems.  These ranges from the Math Fundamentals PoWs (the "funpows"), which targeted grades 3-5, to trig/calculus.  Many of the funpows could be quickly solved with algebraic techniques, but of course, kids in grades 3-5 aren't so likely to pull out algebraic techniques.  So it became a personal challenge to solve every funpow as many ways as you can think of without algebra. Not surprisingly, this gets a lot easier with practice!  While algebra had always been my reflex before, I'm now a lot more flexible in my thinking and approaches to all sorts of problems.


In a reply to Dianne, David comments about how cool it would be to let kids come up with their own problems to answer, much like we asked you to do.  Given an appropriate prompt (one that might elicit math related to the math goals you have for your students at the time), that's really doable.  I've often had teams of students vote for the wonderings they think would be interesting or challenging to answer, and then we use the winner as our focus, with non-winners being additional tasks for some groups who are interested.  I'd say confidently that, other than this one time I used a bad prompt, I have never had kids not wonder the exact thing I wanted them do.  Other regular users of Notice & Wonder report the same thing.


In a related idea, Devon pondered the possibility of using the same story at different grade levels.  That so totally works!  In fact, we once worked with a district that used the same prompt in grades K-8 and then compared results.  First thing you will notice is that younger kids know a TON of math they haven't been "taught", and that they have lots of math ideas.  Many prompts lend themselves to a variety of mathematical goals, and it's super interesting to see what your students come up with.


From a personal math angle on this problem, I would so use a spreadsheet, especially if I was thinking of non-algebraic methods.  I do NOT want to do the arithmetic to recalculate everything based on different numbers of beans for Caleb, but if I teach a spreadsheet the relationships, I can try lots of possible starting numbers.  This might help me notice patterns and will avoid my propensity to make arithmetic errors!

Subject: Looking at Student Work
Msg Text:
Reflection questions:
  • What was it like to see someone else's lens on student work?
  • What did you take away from looking at others' noticing and wondering?
  • Were there any obvious similarities or differences between what you noticed and wondered and what your colleagues did?
I found that in many cases, my peers and I had very similar noticings and wonderings. We focused on the most fundamental areas of need to help students enhance their responses. I was the only one who commented asking a student about the extra problem. From the looks of it, one of my peers may not have realized that the actual word problem students responded to was included in the space. Some of the noticings and wonderings led me to that conclusion. One of my peers did not comment on any student work. Some of my peers focused on commenting about the student work, whereas I commented to the students about their work. One particular group member, though, added a piece to their comments that really stood out to me. In many instances, they made of point of acknowledging and encouraging the student about their processes, bringing an element of SEL support to the activity. I thought this was a great way to show value in the students' thoughts and ideas. They used phrases like, "I notice and appreciate." Other phrases they used were "hidden decisions" to describe work that was clearly considered by the student, but not necessarily explained thoroughly. I could also tell that they attended to the K-12 math practices in their responses. For example, they noticed that a student "persevered" in solving the problem. I love their take in doing it this way because they addressed the gaps to help lead to more fully developed responses, but also provided support from the SEL standpoint. Most of the comments did not specifically tell students what to do, or what errors may have been made, but asked guiding questions to highlight thinking that may lead them to a new noticing.

Subject: Looking through someone else's lens on student work.
Msg Text:
First, I want to complain a little bit.  Trying to figure out how to get my screen in EnCompass to show the things that I needed to click on to be able to see my collaborators' comments was not clear at all.  It took me five minutes to figure out that I have to click those arrow things on the right in order for the window to pop up that was in the explanation of "unselecting my comments only."  A quick video of that would have been helpful.  (If there was one, I didn't find it.)  Thanks.
Now, on to the task at hand...
Reflection questions:
  • What was it like to see someone else's lens on student work?

For the most part, my group members' comments on what they noticed/wondered were in the same vein as mine.  We pretty much picked out the same things to highlight and select from each student, and we had the same comments essentially, even right down to noticing the lack of parentheses in one student's work after the first and into the second line (Cheyenne).  The other collaborator who seems to be done commenting on student's works also commented on this particular student and asked a question about it:  was it a set-up issue or an execution issue?  I would also take this approach if I were in the classroom and the student showed me the work.  That's pretty much the question I would ask her.  So for me, seeing others' lenses on student work really reinforces my own approach and perspective since we shared so much in common.



  • What did you take away from looking at others' noticing and wondering?

I'll phrase this in the sense of notice and wonder here as well because any other way I try and say it sounds negative in some way.  I hope everything comes through in a neutral sense with the notice/wonder form.  I notice that I wrote both notice and wonders for each student, several for some of them in fact.  I notice that my other collaborators must have gone through and thought about key themes across ALL students' works, then picked those out that happened across the students as a whole, and highlighted and commented on those instead of repeating themselves over and over from student to student.  I wonder if I can be as effective in my communications by being more succinct and doing less?



  • Were there any obvious similarities or differences between what you noticed and wondered and what your colleagues did?

This has already been discussed above for the most part.  My collaborators and I really noticed all the same things, right down to where the mistakes were made in Cheyenne's work and the use of color in Destiny's work.  I did notice one thing that no one else seemed to comment on, so that difference would be that I took into consideration if students were working alone or in groups.  In my classroom, I allow students to self-sort when it comes time for these types of problems.  Some prefer to work alone and others really prefer working in groups.  So noticing this from the students' write-ups is an extension of the things I pay attention to in class.

Subject: Reflection: Looking at Peers' Workspaces of Student Work
Msg Text:
Looking at my peer's workspace definitely caused me on to reflect on my own comments, notices and wonders. I asked myself: "Did I just not notice items that my peers noticed and wondered? Were my comments based on certain look-fors or was I really open to what was the student was expressing? Was I limiting myself to just a "pre-determined" number of comments?  " I determined that the answers were yes to all of the questions.


My peers and I typically noted similar notices and wonders. We commented on the student approach to solve the problem -- algebraic, numeric, graphical or words. I believe this is probably because teachers are comfortable using the Rule of 4 either consciencely or unconsciously. We also noted if the final answer was mathematically correct. Thirdly, we commented about the student’s starter numbers for the guess and check strategy as well as how the selection process was changed.  And finally, we commented on the use of mathematical vocabulary to explain their thought process.


I did note several interesting differences between us. The first difference I noted was that the question presented to the students was not the same question presented in module 1. My peers noted that 176 was the total number of beans used by the students. However, it was noted or wondered as a student decision. I believe that I noted the difference due to a teaching emphasis of answering the question asked. Another difference was classifying the error in a notice or wonder.  For example, Cheyenne S work is shown below.

x + x + 8 + 2x - 15 + 30 + (x ÷ 2) = 176
2x + 8 + 2x - 15 + 30 + x ÷ 2 = 176

We all noticed the same point but expressed it differently. One peer noted the error as an order of operation error.  Another peer noticed it as an error with “x divided by 2”.  I noticed the error as combining like terms. My perception was that x divided by 2 should be ½ x with ½ as a coefficient. I believe a better notice would have been an order of operation error.  A third difference I noticed was regarding manipulating fractions. For example, Brian N stated:

            “ 4x+x/2+23=176. After, I multiply the entire equation by 2 to get rid of the fraction”.

Similarly, Destiny stated

            “First, multiply everything by two to get rid of the fraction.”.

Some of my peers considered multiplying by 2 was an efficient strategy to get rid of the fraction. However, “ I noticed that Brian N multiplied by 2 instead of adding 4 + 1/2. I wonder if understands that x/2 is equivalent to (1/2)x.” The final difference was the error in Alyssa M’s equation: 176=(1/2c+30)+(2c-15)+(c+8).  I did not notice the error. Only 1 of my collaborators noted “student didn't consider the amount of bean caleb ate”. However, we all commented through a variety of noticing and wondering that Alyssa M had difficulty solving the equation.

 

By the way, I did just not notice things that my collaborators saw. When I reread the student work, I wonder how I could miss or not think was important. After reading my collaborators workspace I believe that there were several missed opportunities. I believe I had certain look-fors when looking at student work such as creating equations for Sol, Josh and Elsie based on Caleb, writing correct equations, for algebraic solutions -- the use of coefficients, combining like terms and solving equations. I wonder if look-fors are bad in this situation if I can still be flexible in following the student’s thought process. And finally, I believe I was limiting myself to a maximum number of comments per student. But, hey, I am doing that with this reflection.

Msg Text:
It was an interesting experience, and I'm trying to decide what the impact of doing this online is. Some of the things that we were attending to were similar -- for example, when students made unwarranted claims, I noticed a theme of wondering about how students came to such a conclusion. I noticed such wondering in (at least) two distinct categories of students' claims -- the first is when students produced answers (e.g. "Sol was 57.") without providing a calculation that would jutify the answer, and the second is when students would make a process claim (e.g. "I knew I had to start with 44 and then adjust from there.")


One thing I noticed some of my colleagues doing that I had thought about but didn't comment on was in tracking on similarities between student responses -- for example, wondering whether a particular group of students worked together, or whether one student might have shared a hint or strategy with another student. I certainly noticed similarities between student strategies, but didn't really try to track those similarities closely enough that I could make noticings about it (e.g. "I notice that Student 3 and Student 7 used similar strategies."). This is where I wonder about the affordances/constraints of the online system - It would have been much easier to put student work in conversation with each other in an analogue setting by physically moving those two pieces of student work next to each other, or by sorting students into like-strategy groups.

Subject: RE: Looking at Student Work
Msg Text:
It's terrific that someone else in your group incorporated an SEL component to the activity.  I didn't mention that difference in my comments versus my collaborators, but that was another one, in fact.  In addition to the notice and wonder comments, I gave "feedback" comments for some students' work where I thought it was really impressive how much "grit and determination" they showed (Duckworth's phrasing), and relating that and the mistakes learned along the way to a "growth mindset."  Really, yes, all of this falls under the umbrella of perseverance of course in the mathematical practices.  That's what we knew it as before growth mindset, grit, and SEL came along.


In my classroom, I've really made it a priority starting about 4 years ago to purposefully comment on the effort and work a student exhibits.  We celebrate the successes, of course, everyone likes it and feels good when we get the "right" answer.  But building that work ethic and drive to give maximum effort, though intangible and unmeasurable on a standardized test, is really an underlying benefit my students take away (whether they notice it or not).  I know most of them won't need the math itself later in life, but this trait they will.


I still recall the first year I began to consciously try to do this regularly and the reaction one of my honors students had.  I gave my algebra 2 students a graphing project at the end of the year.  I had very high expectations for it.  I was demanding precision and perfection of all the different functions we had covered throughout the year and showing how a, h, and k affect the graphs with several examples.  (It was a portfolio I wanted them to have to take to pre-calc).  I was hand-checking and giving feedback for each student.  One particular honors student kept getting it back with a close, but do this too.  Close, but do this too.  Really close now, but do this too.  After about the fifth or sixth iteration of one particular graph, she finally got it.  Well at this point, she was visibly frustrated as could be (being honors, she wasn't used to having to do things multiple times).  I got down on her level at the desk, looked her in the eys, and told her I was really proud of her for continuing to try, not giving up, taking the feedback into consideration each time, figuring out on her own when to move the opposite direction of the sign and when not to, and persisting so much until the final product was perfect.  She cried (good tears, grateful and happy ones).  It was a really powerful moment for all to see.  That moment sealed the deal for me.  It's a powerful practice, commenting on the work ethic and process and steps along the way, instead of the actual material.

Subject: RE: Reflection: Looking at Peers' Workspaces of Student Work
Msg Text:
It sounds like everyone in your group had similar notices and wonders as those of us in my group.  We all too commented similar things on those same students you mentioned:  Cheyenne, Destiny, Brian, and Alyssa.  Isn't it interesting that those stood out to so many of us for a number of reasons?  These were the ones with typical "math errors" that we're so trained to spot OR they had a different approach than the rest, which we are trained to also spot and highlight for the class at large to show that there's more than one way and promote equity.


As for the differences among us in deciding whether to phrase the comments we provided as notices or wonders, I'll be honest, I had a bit of trouble getting going with the EnCompass software, and I have read in others' reflections the same thing.  Some of my notices/wonders are simply mislabeled due to the novelty of getting to know the software.  I didn't know how to go back in and "fix them."  So, I began writing each and every comment with I notice and I wonder, just to clarify, even if the big N or W in front didn't match what I meant.  I can imagine that if there were differences in your group about the same comment being a notice/wonder, it could easily be attributed to this type of "error."  I can tell you were able to look beyond these distinctions though and focus on the essence underneath.


Your reflections about the process are very introspective and, for me, insightful.  I wonder, indeed, how much our training has us pre-programmed to have certain look-fors, and therefore miss other opportunities that might be fascinating.  One of my classes this year is a group of 9th graders who have never had good math training before, and since it's a small group and there's no expectation of a standardized test for them this year, I'm able to ask about answers they give to questions that just seem SO wrong.  When I give them a chance to explain their work, it's absolutely fascinating the mathematical thoughts and insights they have.  They truly have great instincts and intuition, and their answers are actually very thoughtful.  They usually have simply answered a different question.  It's provided so many opportunities this semester for looking deeply and purposefully into the doing of math for them in a visual way they never had, and that I've never been able to slow down and take time for.

What an amazing story to share! It's so true that the perseverance while working through that productive struggle is so valuable for them to take forward in their lives. I always tell my kids that natural talent can only take you so far. Eventually, those with grit and determination will push past (reminiscent of The Tortoise and the Hare). 


High expectations are wonderful! Many honors' students aren't used to the struggle, which is all the more reason to push them further. I firmly believe that there is no such thing as perfection - we can always take one more step...improve one more degree. What that improvement looks like for each student is vastly different. For some, it may be as foundational as understanding what question is being asked in the math story. For others, it may be as advanced as an extension of the original story.

Subject: RE: Looking at others view of student work
Msg Text: You made a great point about more being revealed by seeing pencil and paper work from the student. That made me think about the discourse that students have about math. Sometimes I feel that as math teachers, we make several inferences about their understanding based on the work that we see them produce. However, if we can help them to be more precise when sharing their work (particularly when writing about it), we can better determine whether their understanding is procedural or conceptual. One of the math practices that comes to mind relates to developing arguments and critiquing reasoning of others' work. True conceptual understanding, and an ability to explain it clearly and concisely, allows students to develop mastery toward their ability to share their thinking and defend their work.

Subject: RE: Looking at student work
Msg Text: It's so easy to go down the "feedback" road, especially when we are in the classroom with deadlines and pacing guides constantly looming. We become focused on the correctness of the answer as opposed to the journey along the way. I attended a training last week with Dr. Nicki Newton and that was one of the things she discussed, but from the perspective of the student. Our students become so focused on solving the problem that they barrel past the beauty of the math. They want to get the "right" answer. I find this to be especially true with my higher level students. One of the things that she suggested, which I've been implementing and have found is helping students to understand better the context, is asking, "What's the story?" When I ask my students about this, I require that their answers involve no numbers. I've found that for many of my students, just this one question helps them to visualize and develop a model that will then allow them to progress in their thinking.

Subject: RE: Group A: Folder Structure and Summary
Msg Text:
Group A met and looked at the structures of the member folders. We discussed that we could create folders dependant on the purpose of the information and what we wanted to use if for. Ultimately we decide that we wanted to create a folder structure that identified trends and misconceptions that would help us planning for the same lesson in the next school year that would help to remind of us of what we saw happening and use that information to plan. We have two overarching folders with sub folders within. The folders could also be used in as a rubric system.

  1. Strategies
    1. Guess and Check
    2. Write and Solve an Equation
    3. Divide by 4 and adjust
    4. No clear or specific strategy
  2. Mathematical Issues
    1. Typo not conceptual error
    2. Incomplete explanation/missing details
    3. Student verified solution
    4. Algebraic errors (ex. incorrectly combine like terms)
  3. Rubric
    1. Beginning
    2. Emergent
    3. Mastery

Subject: Others' Lenses
Msg Text:
Initially, I wasn't able to view others' comments, which provided an opportunity to empathize with students who experience technical difficulties when working with new tools.


Once I was able to view others' comments, it helped me think more deeply about the kinds of communication that will help students move their work forward, persevere in problem-solving, challenge themselves to think more or think differently, and articulate their mathematical understanding in words. It's always nice to get inspiration and see different practices!


Also quite special was when students referred to the kind of feedback they provided peers. At least one student referred to what they told other groups who didn't know how to proceed.


Colleagues noticed similar things, in general, but perhaps placed different emphases or expressed ideas differently. The shared elements would be useful if a group of colleagues were developing a rubric or revising curriculum, as colleagues could see what elements were attended to across the board, as well as which elements might need to be given more attention in the future.


I enjoyed the notice and wonder feedback, as that frame helped me refrain from doing the thinking for students. Mostly, my noticings and wonderings were objective, but I felt the need to drop the objectivity to appreciate and praise mindset, perseverence, and creativity on occasion.

Msg Text:
We chose to share the folder structure that is most straight-forward.  It is simplie in its approach, yet highly effective in its purpose.  It has four categories that comments were sorted into:


equations set up

explanations

guess and check

wonderings


This folder structure organizes the notices/wonders in two ways:  by response type and by respondes.  Going through comments made about student work revealed four major themes,  These were labeled as equations versus guess and check, and explanations versus wonderings.  Keeping the folder structure minimalistic allows these four themes to stand out and speak for themselves, as opposed to being a little more cluttered, buried, and less prominent had there been subfolders and additional categories.  In our discussion about folder structure, we noticed that the purpose of the folders dictated how each of us chose our groupings and folder names.  While some of us took the route described here, another organized folders according to what students actually did.  We see value in both approaches.  Moreover, we can even envision other approaches that might be based on something like the types of feedback given to students (if this were used in a classroom environment).
